standard_metadata.standard_description: Apply the properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions.

hints.content: To factor means to rewrite an expression as a product. Let's try dividing the expression $24j-16$ by each factor.
The following expressions are equivalent to $24j-16$:  - $8(3j-2)$ - $4(6j-4)$
To factor means to rewrite an expression as a product. Let's try dividing the expression $16a+72$ by each factor.

####Factoring out $2$  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}16a+72\\\\ &=2\left(\dfrac{16a+72}{2}\right)\\\\ &=2\left(\dfrac{16a}{2}+\dfrac{72}{2}\right) \\\\ &=2(8a+36) \end{align}$  No, $16a+72$ is *not* equivalent to $2(8+36a)$ or to $2(8a+72)$.
The following expressions are equivalent to $16a+72$:  - $4(4a+18)$ - $8(2a+9)$
To factor means to rewrite an expression as a product. Let's try dividing the expression $64b-16c$ by each factor.
The following expressions are equivalent to $64b-16c$:  - $16(4b-c)$ - $2(32b-8c)$
To factor means to rewrite an expression as a product. Let's try dividing the expression $48-8x$ by each factor.
The following expressions are equivalent to $48-8x$:  - $2(24-4x)$ - $8(6-x)$
To factor means to rewrite an expression as a product. Let's try dividing the expression $72y+108z$ by each factor.
The following expressions are equivalent to $72y+108z$:  - $36(2y+3z)$ - $12(6y+9z)$
To factor means to rewrite an expression as a product. Let's try dividing the expression $18p-36$ by each factor.
The following expressions are equivalent to $18p-36$:  - $2(9p-18)$ - $18(p-2)$
To factor means to rewrite an expression as a product. Let's try dividing the expression $48m+42n$ by each factor.
The following expressions are equivalent to $48m+42n$:  - $6(8m+7n)$ - $3(16m+14n)$
To factor means to rewrite an expression as a product. Let's try dividing the expression $60-36w$ by each factor.
The following expressions are equivalent to $60-36w$:  - $6(10-6w)$ - $12(5-3w)$
To factor means to rewrite an expression as a product. Let's try dividing the expression $20r+60t$ by each factor.
The following expressions are equivalent to $20r+60t$:  - $4(5r+15t)$ - $20(r+3t)$
To factor means to rewrite an expression as a product. Let's try dividing the expression $10h+30+50j$ by each factor.
The following expressions are equivalent to $10h+30+50j$:  - $10(h+3+5j)$ - $2(5h+15+25j)$
To factor means to rewrite an expression as a product. Let's try dividing the expression $64f-64g+96$ by each factor.
The following expressions are equivalent to $64f-64g+96$:  - $8(8f-8g+12)$ - $32(2f-2g+3)$
To factor means to rewrite an expression as a product. Let's try dividing the expression $30-6v-18w$ by each factor.

####Factoring out $2$  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}30-6v-18w\\\\ &=2\left(\dfrac{30-6v-18w}{2}\right)\\\\ &=2\left(\dfrac{30}{2}-\dfrac{6v}{2}-\dfrac{18w}{2}\right) \\\\ &=2(15-3v-9w) \end{align}$  We see that $30-6v-18w$ is equivalent to $2(15-3v-9w)$, not to $2(15-12v)$.
The following expressions are equivalent to $30-6v-18w$:  - $6(5-v-3w)$ - $2(15-3v-9w)$
To factor means to rewrite an expression as a product. Let's try dividing the expression $24k+36q-12$ by each factor.

####Factoring out $12$  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}24k+36q-12\\\\ &=12\left(\dfrac{24k+36q-12}{12}\right)\\\\ &=12\left(\dfrac{24k}{12}+\dfrac{36q}{12}-\dfrac{12}{12}\right) \\\\ &=12(2k+3q-1) \end{align}$  We see that $24k+36q-12$ is equivalent to $12(2k+3q-1)$, not to $12(2k+3q)$.
The following expressions are equivalent to $24k+36q-12$:  - $12(2k+3q-1)$ - $3(8k+12q-4)$
To factor means to rewrite an expression as a product. Let's try dividing the expression $140c+28-14a$ by each factor.

####Factoring out $2$  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}140c+28-14a\\\\ &=2\left(\dfrac{140c+28-14a}{2}\right)\\\\ &=2\left(\dfrac{140c}{2}+\dfrac{28}{2}-\dfrac{14a}{2}\right) \\\\ &=2(70c+14-7a) \end{align}$  No, $140c+28-14a$ is *not* equivalent to $2(70c+28-14a)$ or to $2(70a+14-7c)$.
The following expressions are equivalent to $140c+28-14a$:  - $7(20c+4-2a)$ - $14(10c+2-a)$
To factor means to rewrite an expression as a product. Let's try dividing the expression $99-45f+36b$ by each factor.

####Factoring out $3$  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}99-45f+36b\\\\ &=3\left(\dfrac{99-45f+36b}{3}\right)\\\\ &=3\left(\dfrac{99}{3}-\dfrac{45f}{3}+\dfrac{36b}{3}\right) \\\\ &=3(33-15f+12b) \end{align}$  We see that $99-45f+36b$ is equivalent to $3(33-15f+12b)$, not to $3(33-15+12)$.
The following expressions are equivalent to $99-45f+36b$:  - $9(11-5f+4b)$ - $3(33-15f+12b)$
To factor means to rewrite an expression as a product. Let's try dividing the expression $24m-12p+72$ by each factor.
The following expressions are equivalent to $24m-12p+72$:  - $2(12m-6p+36)$ - $12(2m-p+6)$
To factor means to rewrite an expression as a product. Let's try dividing the expression $28+56t+28w$ by each factor.
The following expressions are equivalent to $28+56t+28w$:  - $28(1+2t+w)$ - $7(4+8t+4w)$
To factor means to rewrite an expression as a product. Let's try dividing the expression $60y-90-20x$ by each factor.

####Factoring out $5$  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}60y-90-20x\\\\ &=5\left(\dfrac{60y-90-20x}{5}\right)\\\\ &=5\left(\dfrac{60y}{5}-\dfrac{90}{5}-\dfrac{20x}{5}\right) \\\\ &=5(12y-18-4x) \end{align}$  We see that $60y-90-20x$ is equivalent to $5(12y-18-4x)$, not to $5(14y-16-4x)$.
The following expressions are equivalent to $60y-90-20x$:  - $5(12y-18-4x)$ - $10(6y-9-2x)$
